awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Causes of Divergent Banking Regulation, 1988-2006
awd_abstract_narration:
SES-1301627 
PI: Frank Dobbin
Co-PI: Kimberly Pernell
Harvard University

Intellectual Merit
Over the past three decades, there has been notable international convergence in banking regulation. The scholarly attention to this regulatory convergence has downplayed important cross-national regulatory differences. However, cross-national variation in regulatory policy has influenced bank outcomes during the recent global financial crisis. Regulators from the G-10 countries did adhere to the same international regulatory standards (i.e. the Basel Capital Accords), but these standards were flexible and ambiguous, and national regulators interpreted and augmented them in different ways. The goal of this dissertation is to explain how and why national banking regulators made the divergent policy choices that they did. To this end, the researchers undertake a comparative historical analysis of the divergent development of banking regulation, 1988-2006, across three Basel Committee member countries: the U.S., Canada, and Spain. Archival material and interviews with domestic banking regulators are used to assess the relative influence of economic, political, institutional, and cultural explanations. This project will improve current understandings of regulatory policy development. Financial markets have grown increasingly salient in the global economy, and it is important to understand the factors that shape their regulation. This project also yields new insights into the deregulation of the U.S. financial system, through analyzing U.S. policy changes in comparative context. 

Broader Impacts
The findings of this study are policy relevant. Particular regulations had serious implications for bank outcomes during the financial crisis, and greater knowledge of the factors that contribute to more or less effective regulation may help international and domestic regulators implement better policy in the future. These findings will also be broadly disseminated to interdisciplinary and non-academic audiences.

por.por_cntn:
This project, my dissertation, examined the divergent development of banking regulation in an era of international regulatory convergence. Banking regulators from the world’s major financial capitals made different policy choices in the years leading up to the recent global financial crisis, despite subscribing to the same international regulatory standards (the Basel Capital Accord). Many of these seemingly minor cross-national differences in regulation had major effects for bank outcomes during the crisis. I sought to reconstruct the processes that drove the development of these important local differences. Drawing from over 5000 pages of archival material and 24 in-depth interviews with banking regulators, I analyzed the historical development of three critical regulations (loan loss provisioning, securitization, the definition of a bank) across three Basel member countries (the U.S., Canada, and Spain). I find that American, Canadian, and Spanish regulators held different understandings about the causes of efficiency and order in the banking system: this directly affected their policy choices. Differences in economic conditions, political pressure (including pressure from large banks), and the structure of the state/regulatory system could not fully explain these divergent policy choices. By demonstrating how local systems of shared meaning continue to inform regulatory policymaking in a globalized world, I improve current understandings of how regulatory policies develop.

The intellectual merit of this dissertation was that the research: 

  • traced the evolution of financial market regulation (including financial deregulation), which has received very little attention in the comparative policy literature.  Given the large and growing importance of financial markets in the global economy, it was important to address this oversight.
  • uncovered a new explanation for the rise of permissive banking regulation in the U.S. This project shed new light on the causes of change in the American financial system, through analyzing American policy shifts in comparative context.
  • addressed unresolved theoretical questions that cut across disciplinary boundaries, including sociology, political science, history, and economics

The broader impacts of the project included:

  • substantively important findings.  I analyzed the development of regulations with serious implications for bank outcomes during the financial crisis.
  • the broad dissemination of findings. I have presented this research to interdisciplinary and non-scientific audiences.
  • policy relevant findings. Understanding how the cultural commitments of regulators drove the development of more or less effective banking regulations should help legislators and the regulatory agencies implement better policies in the future.
